<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[102, 126, 383, 152]]<|/det|> # Cambridge IGCSE™ <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[101, 176, 201, 207]]<|/det|> CANDIDATE NAME <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[101, 226, 180, 256]]<|/det|> CENTRE NUMBER <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[217, 217, 425, 262]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[616, 225, 715, 256]]<|/det|> CANDIDATE NUMBER <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[730, 217, 895, 262]]<|/det|> <|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[102, 280, 186, 297]]<|/det|> ## PHYSICS <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[824, 281, 895, 297]]<|/det|> 0625/51 <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[102, 304, 267, 320]]<|/det|> Paper 5 Practical Test <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[702, 305, 895, 320]]<|/det|> October/November 2020 <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[750, 329, 895, 345]]<|/det|> 1 hour 15 minutes <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[102, 357, 398, 374]]<|/det|> You must answer on the question paper. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[102, 386, 695, 403]]<|/det|> You will need: The materials and apparatus listed in the confidential instructions <|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[102, 420, 230, 435]]<|/det|> ## INSTRUCTIONS <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[102, 435, 798, 558]]<|/det|> INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- You may use a calculator.- You should show all your working and use appropriate units. <|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[102, 586, 221, 601]]<|/det|> ## INFORMATION <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[102, 602, 722, 634]]<|/det|> INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 40.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ]. <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[702, 644, 895, 836]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[289, 860, 707, 877]]<|/det|> This document has 12 pages. Blank pages are indicated.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[89, 79, 104, 98]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[126, 78, 796, 100]]<|/det|>
In this experiment, you will determine the density of modelling clay by two methods.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[126, 109, 212, 128]]<|/det|>
**Method 1**

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[126, 141, 156, 159]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[165, 141, 191, 159]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[201, 140, 908, 177]]<|/det|>
Measure the length \(l\), width \(w\) and height \(h\) of the sample A of modelling clay. Do **not** change the shape of the sample.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[556, 184, 907, 205]]<|/det|>
<form>l = ....................................................... $cm$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[551, 214, 907, 234]]<|/det|>
<form>w = ....................................................... $cm$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[554, 244, 907, 265]]<|/det|>
<form>h = ....................................................... $cm$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[880, 261, 907, 280]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 291, 191, 310]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[201, 291, 771, 312]]<|/det|>
Calculate the volume \(V_{\mathrm{A}}\) of sample A using the equation \(V_{\mathrm{A}} = l\times w\times h\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[541, 330, 907, 352]]<|/det|>
<form>V<sub>A</sub> = .................................................. $cm^3$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 364, 191, 383]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[200, 363, 907, 399]]<|/det|>
Measure and record the mass \(m_{\mathrm{A}}\) of sample A of modelling clay using the balance provided.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[539, 408, 907, 429]]<|/det|>
<form>m<sub>A</sub> = .................................................... $g$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[880, 409, 907, 428]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 440, 190, 459]]<|/det|>
<label>(iv)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[200, 433, 724, 462]]<|/det|>
Calculate the density \(\rho_{\mathrm{A}}\) of sample A using the equation \(\rho_{\mathrm{A}} = \frac{m_{\mathrm{A}}}{V_{\mathrm{A}}}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[201, 467, 907, 504]]<|/det|>
Give your answer to a suitable number of significant figures for this method and include the unit.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[475, 514, 907, 536]]<|/det|>
<form>$\rho_{\mathrm{A}} =$ .......................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[880, 516, 907, 535]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[91, 560, 175, 579]]<|/det|>
<label>Method 2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[126, 591, 158, 609]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[165, 590, 781, 611]]<|/det|>
Pour approximately \(50 \text{cm}^3\) of the water provided into the measuring cylinder.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[163, 621, 191, 640]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[201, 621, 660, 641]]<|/det|>
Record the volume \(V_{1}\) of water in the measuring cylinder.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[541, 650, 907, 672]]<|/det|>
<form>V<sub>1</sub> = .................................................... $cm^3$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[201, 682, 907, 718]]<|/det|>
Carefully lower sample B of the same modelling clay into the measuring cylinder until it is completely covered with water.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[201, 727, 772, 747]]<|/det|>
Record the new reading \(V_{2}\) of the water level in the measuring cylinder.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[541, 757, 907, 778]]<|/det|>
<form>V<sub>2</sub> = .................................................... $cm^3$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[201, 788, 764, 809]]<|/det|>
Calculate the volume \(V_{\mathrm{B}}\) of sample B using the equation \(V_{\mathrm{B}} = V_{2} - V_{1}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[541, 861, 907, 883]]<|/det|>
<form>V<sub>B</sub> = .................................................... $cm^3$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[880, 878, 907, 897]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 79, 191, 98]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[201, 78, 907, 115]]<|/det|>
Measure and record the mass \(m_{\mathrm{B}}\) of sample B of measuring clay using the balance provided.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[536, 125, 907, 147]]<|/det|>
<form>\(m_{\mathrm{B}} =\) ........................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[201, 151, 727, 175]]<|/det|>
Calculate the density \(\rho_{\mathrm{B}}\) of sample B using the equation \(\rho_{\mathrm{B}} = \frac{m_{\mathrm{B}}}{V_{\mathrm{B}}}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[201, 184, 907, 220]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[541, 230, 907, 250]]<|/det|>
<form>\(\rho_{\mathrm{B}} =\) ........................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[880, 247, 907, 265]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[163, 275, 907, 312]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[163, 322, 907, 358]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[89, 79, 104, 98]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[126, 78, 841, 100]]<|/det|> In this experiment, you will investigate the magnification of the image produced by a lens. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[126, 109, 670, 131]]<|/det|> Carry out the following instructions referring to Fig. 3.1 and Fig. 3.2. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[134, 136, 860, 275]]<|/det|> <|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[465, 289, 532, 308]]<|/det|> <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[252, 327, 744, 425]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[299, 437, 695, 458]]<|/det|> Fig. 3.2 This figure has **not** been drawn to scale. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[126, 467, 156, 486]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[165, 467, 866, 489]]<|/det|> Measure and record the height \(h_{\mathrm{O}}\) of the illuminated object provided in your experiment. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[541, 496, 908, 518]]<|/det|>
h_{\mathrm{O}} = .................................................... [1] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[126, 528, 156, 547]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[170, 528, 724, 549]]<|/det|> Place the lens a distance \(u = 20.0 \text{cm}\) from the illuminated object. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[165, 559, 824, 580]]<|/det|> Move the screen slowly until a clearly-focused image is formed on the screen. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[165, 590, 908, 625]]<|/det|> Measure the distance \(\nu\) between the centre of the lens and the screen and record the value in Table 3.1. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[165, 632, 851, 658]]<|/det|> Calculate, and record in Table 3.1, the magnification \(m\) using the equation \(m = \frac{\nu}{u}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[163, 664, 905, 686]]<|/det|> Repeat the procedure using values of \(u\) equal to 25.0 cm, 30.0 cm, 35.0 cm and 40.0 cm. <|ref|>table_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[457, 695, 539, 714]]<|/det|> Table 3.1 <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[321, 725, 675, 875]]<|/det|>
\(u/\mathrm {cm}\)\(v/\mathrm {cm}\)\(m\)

25.0
30.0
35.0
40.0

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[126, 78, 576, 100]]<|/det|>
A student investigates the resistances of different wires.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[126, 109, 814, 131]]<|/det|>
Plan an experiment to investigate the resistances of wires made from different metals.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[126, 133, 907, 178]]<|/det|>
Resistance is calculated using the equation \(R = \frac{V}{I}\). You are **not** required to carry out the investigation.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[126, 186, 423, 206]]<|/det|>
The following apparatus is available:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[126, 217, 203, 234]]<|/det|>
ammeter

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[126, 231, 207, 248]]<|/det|>
voltmeter
